ic.overview.title: Hello!
ic.overview.summary:
Welcome to the WristAngel study.

In this app you will have access to the tasks and exercises of the WristAngel study. Before we begin, we want to tell you about the study and your participation.

If you are under 18, please go through this with your parent.
ic.who.title: Who are we?
ic.who.summary:
This study is conducted by researchers and clinicians from the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Center, Capital Region of Denmark and the Technical University of Denmark.

The main contact person is psychologist Nicole Lønfeldt.

Funding for this study comes from the Novo Nordisk Foundation.
ic.who.content:
PROJECT TEAM

This research is done in collaboration between the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Center, Research Unit, Capital Region of Denmark and the Copenhagen Center for Health Technology (CACHET) at the Technical University of Denmark (DTU).

The investigators directly working with this study include: 

 - Professor Anne Katrine Pagsberg and Senior Scientist Nicole Lønfeldt from the research unit of the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Center
 - Associate Professor Line Clemmensen and Postdoc Sneha Das from DTU
 - Professor Jakob E. Bardram and PhD student Giovanna Nunes Vilaza from DTU.

PROJECT FUNDING

This study is funded by the Novo Nordisk Foundation’s Exploratory Interdisciplinary Synergy Program. The grant reference number is NNF19OC0056795. The investigators have no financial connection to the funders.
ic.tasks.title: What is this study for?
ic.tasks.summary:
For the next 8 weeks, there will be tasks and questions for you or your child to complete every day as part of the study.

This data is collected to help us to understand how the therapeutic process is evolving with time.

The results of the study will then improve the assessment and treatment of future patients.
ic.tasks.content:
PROJECT GOALS

We aim to improve assessment and psychotherapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in children and adolescents through digital tools for patients, parents, and therapists. 

We aim to give an innovative push to public sector hospitals and research by integrating wearable sensors and machine learning techniques. This project's results will also advance research in computational science and psychiatry by testing biomarkers of clinical relevance.

In this study, we will test the feasibility of implementing digitally enhanced psychotherapy and research in a community child and adolescent mental health center, including mobile and wearable devices' acceptability to patients, parents, and therapists.

STUDY TASKS

Study tasks include (1) daily surveys to register emotional states (Positive and Negative Affect Schedule) and distress levels before and after exposure practice, and (2) weekly surveys to measure symptoms, acceptability, trust and user experience with the wristband and the study app.

Data collected from this study will be analyzed and shared by researchers at DTU and medical researchers in the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Center. Results from this study will be published in an anonymized format in scientific journals and other scientific forums and may be presented at scientific conferences. Dissemination of the research results will be completely anonymous and will not contain any individual-identifiable information. We strive for open-access publication, which means that access to the research results is available for all free of cost.
ic.duration.title: When can we see your answers?
ic.duration.summary:
Through this study you will provide us with information about how you feel and your experiences in using the app and the wristband. 

We will first see your answers at the end of the study and NOT while you are part of the study.

If you or your child need help with emotional problems or other health issues, please contact your regular healthcare provider. 

If you need help with using the app or the wristband, please contact us directly.
ic.data.title: How is your data handled?
ic.data.summary:
This app collects personal data including your e-mail address and your name, as well as your answers.

The access to data is restricted to the project's researchers, and data will not be shared with third parties.

The legal entity responsible for controlling the data from this study is the Technical University of Denmark.
ic.data.content:
DATA HANDLING

Your personal data is processed in compliance with the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The Technical University of Denmark, CVR no. 30060946, is the data controller responsible for personal data in this study. Identifiable data can only be accessed by the researchers affiliated with this project. Information will not be shared with your case worker, but you are welcome to share study information with your case worker. 

DATA HANDLING

No data is stored on your smartphone, only processed using a pseudonym so that your information is not linked to your identity. All communication between your smartphone and our server is encrypted. All server-side services, including web applications, can only be accessed by authenticated and authorized users. The data is encrypted and hosted on servers within EU.

You can get a digital copy of the data being collected about you in this study by contacting the principle investigator.
ic.location.title: Why is location enabled?
ic.location.summary: This study do not collect location data but uses the location service on the phone.
ic.location.content:
This study does not collect location data.

But we ask you to enable the location service on the phone by allowing tracking of location 'Always', since the location service is used to keep the app running in the background.

The location service is used to make sure that the questionnaires are triggered when needed.
ic.rights.title: What are your rights?
ic.rights.summary:
Participation should be voluntary and harmless. You and your child are free to stop using the app at any time. If you have any negative experiences, please inform us.

You also have the right to have your individual data records deleted after the study.

If you are interested in receiving the research results, you can request them from the project team.
ic.rights.content:
PARTICIPANT'S RIGHTS

We are not aware of any major risks or safety issues associated with the participation in this study. If your child is a patient, and suffers injuries due to the research project, you can apply for compensation under the Patient Insurance Act.

The ethics committee of the Capital Region of Denmark approved the WristAngel study (journal number: H-18010607-79689).

Your participation is voluntary, and you are free to withdraw your consent at any time, without providing a reason. Doing so will have no adverse effect on your legal rights. We will contact you to ask for your consent if we ever need to use your survey data for a similar study.

If you like, you can choose to have your data deleted after the study or if you withdraw early. You can also receive the results of the surveys once the research is complete if you contact us by e-mail. The compensation you receive for using this app is what you receive for the study overall.

CONTACT

The main contact person is Senior Scientist Nicole Nadine Lønfeldt, CAMHS Bispebjerg: rhp-fp-wrist-angel@regionh.dk
ic.summary.title: Summary before consent
ic.summary.summary:
You are above 18 years old. If you are not, please go through this with your parent. 

You have read and understood the provided information and have had the opportunity to ask questions.

You understand your rights: your participation is voluntary, and you are free to withdraw at any time.

You understand and agree with how your data is collected, stored and used.
ic.review.title: Informed Consent
ic.review.reason: Have you read, understood and agreed with using this app for the study as explained?
ic.completion.title: Thank you!
ic.completion.text: We have saved your consent document.
study.description.title: Wrist Angel: A Wearable AI Feedback Tool for OCD Treatment and Research
study.description.purpose: We aim to improve assessment and psychotherapy for pediatric obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
study.description.description: Hormone levels, measured in saliva, and physiological indicators of stress from children and parents are used as input to privacy preserving signal processing and machine learning algorithms. Signal processing will be used to extract acoustic and physiological features of importance for therapeutic response. The study includes children with an OCD diagnosis and children without a psychiatric diagnosis and their parents.
study.responsible.name: Nicole Nadine Lønfeldt
study.responsible.title: Senior Scientist
study.responsible.affiliation: Child and Adolescent Mental Health Centre – Research Unit, Capital Region of Denmark
survey.answerFormat.instensity.slightly: Very slightly or not at all
survey.answerFormat.company.child: I am with my child who is participating in the study
survey.answerFormat.company.other.child: I am with my child(ren) who is/are not participating in the study

survey.answerFormat.discomfort.future.mo: My discomfort/fear/disgust will grow and grow until I can't take it any more
survey.answerFormat.discomfort.future.le: I will feel less discomfort/fear/disgust over time
survey.answerFormat.reward.tvshow: Watch an episode of my favorite series
survey.answerFormat.reward.plan: Do something fun with friends/ family (make a plan)
survey.answerFormat.reward.other: I will do something not listed here
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.dirt: Fear/ disgust of pollution, infection, dirt, bacteria, diseases
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.harm: Fear of harming myself or others (physically or emotionally)
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.sexuality: Disturbing thoughts/ images about sex, pregnancy or sexuality
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.collect: Need to collect things or fear of losing something
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.superstitio: Magical/superstitious thoughts or actions (e.g. lucky numbers or words; stepping on a crack can break someone’s back)
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.disease: Worry about having a disease or that a body part or your appearance looks wrong
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.offense: Fear of offending God or Satan or worry about what is right and wrong
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.symmetry: Symmetry and order (e.g. that things must lie in a certain way, or things must be in order)
survey.answerFormat.obsesion.right: Needing to do something until it feels right or not wrong
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.checking: Checking (like if you have remembered to lock the door)
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.repeating: Repeating actions (like turning the lights on and off several times)
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.fixing: Fixing things or trying to get things in a certain place or symmetrical
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.collectin: Collecting things or difficulty throwing things away
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.superstit: Magical/superstitious behavior (like doing or saying things a certain number of times to prevent something bad from happening)
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.parents: Involving your parents in a ritual or asking for reassurance
survey.answerFormat.compulsion.right: Doing something until it feels right
survey.answerFormat.discomfort.more: My discomfort grew until I couldn’t stand it anymore
survey.answerFormat.discomfort.mixed: My discomfort went up and down
survey.answerFormat.discomfort.same: My discomfort did not really change
survey.answerFormat.discomfort.less: I felt less discomfort with time
survey.symptoms.obsessions.title: Symptom Hierarchy: Obsessions
survey.symptoms.obsessions.description: This form is designed to help you keep track of how your obsessions change from week to week.
survey.symptoms.obsessions.instruction.t:
Symptom Hierarchy: Obsessions


Obsessions are unwanted thoughts or images that keep popping into your head and that you can't stop thinking about, even though you want to be rid of them.

On the next pages, you will see obsessions that many people with OCD have. Tell us how upset or scared each obsession has been for you over the past week by choosing the number that best matches how you feel. 0 means that you have not had the obsession or that it is not at all unpleasant and 10 means that the obsession is so upsetting you can’t stand it.
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.1.ti: Fear/ disgust of pollution, infection, dirt, bacteria, diseases
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.2.ti: Fear of harming yourself or others (body or feelings)
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.3.ti: Disturbing thoughts/ images about sex, pregnancy or sexuality
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.4.ti: Need to collect things or fear of losing something
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.5.ti: Magical/superstitious thoughts or actions (e.g. lucky numbers or words; stepping on a crack can break someone’s back)
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.6.ti: Worry about having a disease or that a body part or your appearance looks wrong
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.7.ti: Fear of offending God or Satan or worry about what is right and wrong
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.8.ti: Symmetry and order (e.g. that things must lie in a certain way, or things must be in order)
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.9.ti: Needing to do something until it feels right or not wrong
survey.symptoms.obsessions.question.10.t: Here you can describe other obsessions that have not been mentioned
You are finished recording your obsessions for this week. By keeping track of your obsessions and compulsions, you're taking back control, so OCD doesn't control you.
survey.symptoms.compulsions.title: Symptom Hierarchy: Compulsions
survey.symptoms.compulsions.description: This form is designed to help you keep track of how your compulsions change from week to week.
Symptom hierarchy: Compulsions


Compulsions are things that OCD wants you to do. If you try to resist doing these things or try not to do what OCD tells to, you may feel afraid, worried, frustrated, angry or upset.

On the next pages there will be some compulsions that many people with OCD have. Tell us how upset each compulsion (or trying to resist the compulsion) has been for you over the past week by choosing the number that best matches how you feel. 0 means that you do not have that compulsion or that does not bother you and 10 means that the compulsion upsets you so much that you can’t stand it.
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.2.t: Checking (like if you have remembered to lock the door)
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.3.t: Repeating actions (like turning the lights on and off several times)
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.5.t: Fixing things or try to get things the same or symmetrical
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.6.t: Collecting things or difficulty throwing things away
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.7.t: Magical/superstitious behavior (e.g. doing or saying things a certain number of times to prevent something terrible from happening)
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.8.t: Involving others (like your parents) in a ritual or asking for reassurance
survey.symptoms.compulsions.question.9.t: Needing to do something until it feels right
Here you can describe other compulsions that have not been mentioned
survey.symptoms.compulsions.completition: You are finished recording your compulsions for this week. By keeping track of your obsessions and compulsions, you're taking back control, so OCD doesn't control you.
survey.symptoms.exposure.title: Weekly exposure and response prevention
survey.symptoms.exposure.description: Describe the obsession and/or the compulsion you are working on
survey.symptoms.exposure.question.1.text: How scared or upset do you feel?
survey.trustscale.title: Trust in the Mobile App
survey.trustscale.description: We would like to know what it was like for you to use the mobile app
survey.trustscale.instruction.text:
We would like to know what it was like for you to use the mobile app.

Please read each statement and chose the number (0, 1, 2, or 3) that best describes how you feel.
survey.trustscale.question.1.title: I believe that there could be negative consequences when using this mobile app
survey.trustscale.question.2.title: I feel I must be cautious when using this mobile app
survey.trustscale.question.3.title: It is risky to interact with this mobile app
survey.trustscale.question.4.title: I think that this mobile app is competent and effective in supporting the research study
survey.trustscale.question.5.title: I think that this mobile app performs its role as a tool for research very well
survey.trustscale.question.6.title: I believe that this mobile app has all the functionalities I would expect from a research study app
survey.trustscale.question.7.title: When I use this mobile app, I feel I can count on it completely
survey.trustscale.question.8.title: I can always rely on the mobile app for guidance and assistance
survey.trustscale.question.9.title: I can trust the information presented to me by the mobile app
survey.trustscale.question.10.title: I believe that the mobile app provides me with benefits
survey.trustscale.question.11.title: I believe that the mobile app will show me how to get support if I need help
survey.trustscale.question.12.title: I believe that the mobile app attends to my needs and preferences
survey.trustscale.question.13.title: Is there anything else you would like to tell us about your experience?
survey.trustscale.completition.title: Thank you for completing the product evaluation questionnaire!
survey.informedconsent.title: Evaluation of the mobile app consent
survey.informedconsent.description: We would like to know your experience with the informed consent
survey.informedconsent.instruction.text:
Please make your evaluation of the app informed consent now.

The questionnaire consists of attributes that may apply to the app informed consent. You can express your agreement with the attributes by ticking the option that most closely reflects your impression.

It is your personal opinion that counts. Please remember: there is no wrong or right answer!
survey.informedconsent.completition.titl: Thank you for completing the trust evaluation questionnaire!
survey.appux.title: User Experience with the Mobile App
survey.appux.description: We would like to know your experience with the app
survey.appux.instruction.text:
Please make your evaluation of this mobile app now.

The questionnaire consists of attributes that may apply to the app. You can express your agreement with the attributes by ticking the option that most closely reflects your impression.

It is your personal opinion that counts. Please remember: there is no wrong or right answer!
survey.appux.completition.title: Thank you for completing the app evaluation questionnaire!

survey.exposure.title: Fight back against OCD
survey.exposure.description: Describe the obsession and/or the compulsion you are working on
survey.exposure.instruction.1.title: Exposure and response prevention
survey.exposure.instruction.1.text:
This survey is designed to help you practice fighting OCD. To take back control from OCD, you must do the opposite of what OCD wants you to do. For example, you may touch some food left over on your plate or say some “dangerous” words. Or, if the OCD tells you to touch things a certain number of times, don't do it. Going against OCD can be scary or upsetting. But, to take control back from OCD, you can’t run away from the discomfort or fear - you must tough it out.

During the exercise, notice what happens to the feeling of discomfort for up to 15 minutes.

While you practice going against OCD, your parents or your therapist can help you use this form.
survey.exposure.question.1.text: What do you think is going to happen to your feelings of discomfort, fear or disgust when you practice doing the opposite of what OCD wants you to do?
survey.exposure.instruction.2.text:
Many children and adolescents think that their fear or discomfort will get worse and worse when they practice going against OCD, but that is not what happens.

For many children and adolescents, the fear/discomfort goes up and down during the exercise. For some people, the fear/discomfort becomes less during the exercise. Others find that their fear/discomfort does not really change during the exercise, but then they learn that fear and discomfort are not dangerous. With lots of practice, you may notice that you feel less fear, disgust or discomfort.
survey.exposure.question.2.text:
Before you start practicing going against OCD, prepare for the exercise by answering some questions.

You're going to do something difficult and that should be rewarded. How will you reward yourself after the exercise of fighting OCD?
survey.exposure.question.3.text:
In the exercise, I will work on an obsession.

(Obsessions are unwanted thoughts or images that keep popping into your head and that you can't stop thinking about, even though you want to be rid of them.)
survey.exposure.question.4.text: The obsession I want to work on now is about:
survey.exposure.question.5.text: You can describe the obsession you want to on work on here, if you would like to describe it detail or if you could not find an obsession in the list.
survey.exposure.question.6.text:
I want to work with a compulsion.


(Compulsions are things that OCD wants you to do. If you try to resist doing these things or try not to do what OCD tells you to, you may feel afraid, worried, frustrated, angry or upset.)
survey.exposure.question.7.text: The compulsion I will work on is about:
survey.exposure.question.8.text: You can describe the compulsion you want to work on here, if you would like to describe it detail or if you could not find a compulsion in the list.
survey.exposure.question.9.text: Describe how you will practice going against OCD. How do you want to work on the obsession and/or compulsion (for example touching the toilet seat or making your desk messy):
survey.exposure.instruction.3.text:
On the next pages, you will be asked to note how much fear or discomfort you experience while you go against OCD.

Start by noting how uncomfortable it is for you to think about doing the exercise you just described on a scale of 0 to 10. 0 means that you are completely calm or not at all afraid. 10 means that you are so scared or upset you can’t stand it.
survey.exposure.question.10.text: How much discomfort do you feel after 1 minute?
survey.exposure.question.11.text: How much discomfort do you feel after 3 minutes?
survey.exposure.question.12.text: How much discomfort do you feel after 5 minutes?
survey.exposure.question.13.text: How much discomfort do you feel after 7 minutes?
survey.exposure.question.14.text: How much discomfort do you feel after 10 minutes?
survey.exposure.question.15.text: How much discomfort do you feel after 15 minutes?
survey.exposure.question.16.text:
Well done! You stayed with some difficult feelings!

What happened to those difficult feelings when you practiced doing the opposite of what OCD wants?
survey.exposure.completition.title: You are done with the exercise!
survey.exposure.completition.text: Remember to give yourself that reward

audio.exposure.description: Describe the exposure exercise you are working on
audio.exposure.instructions: Describe the exposure exercise: how will you work on the obsession or compulsion?
audio.exposure.name: Exposure exercise
